On Fri, Mar 10, 2017 at 11:46 PM, Craig Tiller <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> *@ctiller* commented on this pull request.
> ------------------------------
>
> In tools/jenkins/run_performance.sh
> <https://github.com/grpc/grpc/pull/10079#discussion_r105505057>:
>
> > @@ -34,4 +34,5 @@ set -ex
>  # Enter the gRPC repo root
>  cd $(dirname $0)/../..
>
> -tools/run_tests/run_performance_tests.py -l c++ node ruby csharp python --netperf --category smoketest
> +tools/run_tests/run_microbenchmark.py -c summary --diff_perf origin/$ghprbTargetBranch
>
> Let's move the performance suites into the regular unit test jobs (and run
> them concurrently if we can)
>
AFAIK, we have *never* gated a PR on the outcome of this job, which means
> that the idea of running them in an isolated pool is invalid: we don't use
> the numbers, we just use the success fail bit.
>
I get the point that we actually weren't looking at the numbers (but maybe
we should have and now we could use the same PR commenting technique that's
used in this PR - it would become more interesting once we
actually get to some perf optimization work in wrapped languages - and I'm
hoping it's going to be sooner than later).

We could probably probably turn some of the performance tests into unit
tests, but there's problems with that:
1. The benchmarks should run two separate processes and given how running
tests works in wrapped languages (basically every language has its own
testing framework that runs the tests), it's a non-trivial amount of
work to migrate the tests.
2. Some scenarios (like wrapped_lang_client vs c++ server) are impossible
to run by this technique. Yet in the past some of these scenarios have been
failing and it has revealed some bugs.
3. If we want to reveal potential issues with performance tests on master,
we should run a suite that's as similar as possible on pull requests.
That's the only reliable way to prevent breakages. From my experience, if
some performance scenarios get broken on master, it can take up to weeks
before someone notices (especially if it's just one scenario from many). I
want us to know about breakages before PRs get merged, not after.

To be honest, I don't understand where is the urge to kill existing &
working tests coming from, considering you could just as easily add a new
jenkins job for microbenchmarks (and we could discuss killing existing
tests separately).

I'm additionally ok if we disable the running of wrapped language qps tests
> for a few weeks (even up to a month) at this point in the release cycle
> until we can get things migrated.
>
I would have been fine with that if:
1. owners of wrapped languages would be involved in the decision
2. we had a confirmation that every lang. owner has cycles to actually work
on this (which I doubt).
3. OR we actually first added the unit tests first and then killed the
existing perf PR suite (which seems to be the most reasonable approach btw).

Otherwise I have zero confidence that we would actually add the replacement
perf unit tests in all the languages. We can discuss this offline if you
wish.
